subtitle: Federal outlays equal about 22–23% of GDP. During a lapse in appropriations, many activities funded by annual discretionary spending (about 6% of GDP) are suspended (as of Oct 2025).

economic_loss.banner: Forecasters estimate a 0.1–0.2 percentage point reduction in annualized quarterly GDP growth per week of shutdown (most recovers after reopening) (as of Oct 2025).

header.title: Discretionary outlays as a share of GDP (context for affected activities)

items.title: Federal workers unpaid
items.detail: Hundreds of thousands of employees are furloughed; many essential personnel continue working with pay delayed until appropriations resume (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Contractors miss payments
items.detail: Federal contractors generally are not guaranteed back pay for time lost during a shutdown (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Services halted
items.detail: Selected services pause or slow, including some passport and visa processing, certain IRS operations, and some national park access (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Household spending declines
items.detail: Household discretionary purchases may be reduced in affected areas (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Business activity deferred
items.detail: Some hiring, permits, reviews, and projects are postponed while agencies are limited (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Market volatility increases
items.detail: IPO and ETF approvals can be delayed when agency operations are limited; financial volatility can increase (as of Oct 2025).

timeline_2025.title: Political Timeline: 2025 Shutdown
timeline_2025.events: See timeline.json for verified chronology (as of Oct 2025).

consumer_confidence.title: Consumer Confidence Index (CCI): 2025 Shutdown
consumer_confidence.note: Estimates subject to revision. Source: Conference Board

items.title: Tourism operations reduced
items.detail: National parks, museums, and monuments may reduce operations during a lapse (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Economic releases suspended
items.detail: Some federal statistical releases, including labor market and inflation reports, can be delayed during agency closures (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Credit rating review possible
items.detail: Rating agencies note that shutdowns are a negative governance factor; extended lapses can prompt review commentary (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Debt ceiling considerations
items.detail: Shutdowns are distinct from the debt limit, but overlapping fiscal disputes can add uncertainty (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Assistance program disruptions
items.detail: Some housing, childcare, and nutrition program operations can face interruptions depending on available balances and state execution (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Private sector employment effects
items.detail: Past shutdowns produced temporary employment disruptions; limited lasting effects were noted after reopening (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Contractor payment delays
items.detail: Contractor invoices may be delayed, creating cash‑flow strain (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Regional economic effects
items.detail: Businesses near federal facilities often report lower foot traffic during shutdowns (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Limited compensation options
items.detail: Most small contractors are not eligible for back pay enacted for federal employees (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Investor monitoring
items.detail: International investors monitor U.S. fiscal developments during shutdowns (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Trade negotiations
items.detail: Some partners may adjust negotiation timelines amid uncertainty (as of Oct 2025).

items.title: Geopolitical observations
items.detail: Rating agencies cite governance considerations when assessing sovereign outlooks (as of Oct 2025).

footer.sources: Congressional Budget Office, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Government Accountability Office, White House Council of Economic Advisers, Reuters, Associated Press, S&P Global, EY-Parthenon, Conference Board
